This is made easy by understanding F = ma. Both the moon and the earth exert the same amount of force (F) on each other. But the moon accelerates much more, obviously. If the F acting on both the moon and the earth are equal, then:

For the moon, F = (low mass)*(high acceleration)

For the earth, F = (high mass)*(low acceleration)

The object of lower mass must accelerate more, the object of higher mass must accelerate less.

One reason everyone got it wrong is that they were thinking of fields instead of forces. Yes, the forces on Earth and the moon are equal (and opposite): F = GMm/r^2, where M is Earth's mass and m is the moon's mass. But Earth's gravitational field acting on the moon is GM/r^2, whereas the moon's field acting on Earth is only Gm/r^2. The other reason is that the acceleration of the moon is F/m, while that of Earth is only F/M. So the ratio of the moon's acceleration to Earth's is M/m, which is equal to about 80.

Somebody asked, “Why did people think the sun revolved around the earth?” And the answer was, “Because that’s the way it appears,” to which another question was asked, “What it would it look like the other way?” That’s pretty powerful. It would look the same. So why do we conclude the former? Because of our perspective...and this is a reasonable conclusion (unless we are taught differently), because our eyes are designed to not fool us. In cases like the sun and earth, this evolutionary characteristic works against us, but this is mostly not the case.

if a bigger person runs into a smaller person, the bigger person will 'affect'

What this explanation lacks:

Now consider the acceleration of both of these objects. In the first case we apply the force F to each of these objects, both of them weigh 1 kg, as such they both have an acceleration F (numerically speaking here). In the second case each of the three masses on the left is 1 kg and experiences a force F, and as such has an acceleration F, and so the whole system has an acceleration F. On the right though, we have three of the forces F acting upon the same 1kg object in the same direction, resulting in acceleration 3F. So even though both forces are the same, their effects differ.

Another way to see Newton's third law is the formula gravitational acceleration g = γ*M/r², where γ (or G, depending where you live) is the gravitational constant, M is the mass of one object and r is the distance between two objects from their center. The formula for the gravitational force is F=mg but that only applies if you know g beforehand. The full formula is F = γ*m*M/r². As you can see, both objects experience the same force, no matter how massive M and m are. Swapping the masses doesn't affect the mass either.
The total force the Earth and the moon experience through gravity is is about 221 997 903 067 494 051 871 N or about 2.2^2 * 10^20 N. Due to the Earth bigger mass, it accelerates (if they were the only objects and both inital speed were 0 m/s) slower towards the moon than than the moon does to the Earth (the Earth about 3.72 * 10^(-5) m/s² and the moon about 3.02 * 10^(-3) m/s²).

The forces do not cancel because they are not acting on the same object.  Forces only cancel when they act on the same object - like when you stand on the surface of the Earth.

The force of gravity pulls YOU down with a force.  The ground pushes up on YOU with an equal and opposite force.  Both of these forces act on YOU - thus cancel, and you do not move.

When you push a wall with a force, that wall exerts an equal and opposite force back on you.  One of these forces is acting on THE WALL - the other equal and opposite counterpart is acting ON YOU.  The wall does not move because it is fixed (for all intents and purposes).  You move backward consistent with the force the wall exerted on you - which is equal to the force you exerted on the wall.

Make sense? - - - if you even read this!!

The law by itself doesn't give the reality of the situation if taken alone, and a misunderstanding demonstrates a confusion between force and acceleration. The relationship F=ma with constant m (mass), or as Derek pointed out, inertia, must be taken into consideration. In a sense, we can say mass IS inertia, or to be more precise, mass is what quantifies resistance to change in motion. Just because two objects are experiencing equal and opposite forces, does not mean they are experiencing accelerations equal in magnitude. The acceleration of each object is proportional to the force by mass. Rewriting F=ma as F/m = a, it becomes more apparent the larger the mass, the smaller the acceleration, and vice versa. Thus two objects can experience the same force but different accelerations due to their different masses.

TRUE that the force is the same during interaction, BUT, the effect is NOT the inertia, but rather the Newton's 2nd law.. More like a derived conclusion from the Newton's 2nd law - i.e the following:

The "effect" - i.e. - the acceleration the E and the M would get are the following: ae = F/me, and the acceleration of the moon would be am = F/ mm

Where ae and am are the accelerations of the Earth and the Moon, whilest me and mm are their masses respectively

Now - let's say that the densities of the Earth and the Moon are relatable to each other - more like - ge ~ gm, or even better - say that ge = K*gm.. Where K is the relational coefficient of the densities of the Earth and Moon..

Now there's a bit of a formula conversions, using math of a volume of a mass.. And if we approximately assume that both the Earth and the Moon have a Spheric form - means the following:

am ~ F/rm^3, and ae ~ F/re^3..

In other words - the effect of the gravitational force reflecting the Earth and Moon are proportionate to the reciprocical value of the 3rd power of the Earth and Moon's radius..

Now - in your example of a basketball, and a tennis ball - assuming by eye that the radius of the basketball would be around 3 times bigger - means that the effect of the interactinal force between the two would be 27 times smaller on the basketball than the tennis ball.. As for the Earth and Moon case - that's EVEN MUCH MORE DRASTIC - more like 500 to 1 (don't know the exact number here TBH) in radius - means around 1.25 billion times smaller the effect of the gravitational force on the Earth rather than the Moon..

TRUE - that people "interchange" force and "effect", BUT - almost everything else was said wrong

The 2 forces can't be "the same". They have the same magnitude (strength, size, length) but they're not the same. We say that 2 forces are equal (the same) when they have both the same strength and the same direction. In this case, the force of the Earth on the moon points in the opposite direction as that of the moon on the Earth. So, at least mathematically, they are 2 distinct forces.
In short, yes. It's just that this same force has a MUCH bigger effect on the stone than it does on the Earth, because the Earth is so much more massive.

While you're correct that the gravitational acceleration of the Earth on the moon is larger than that of the moon on the Earth, I don't think this justifies the incorrect answers. It is precisely the connection between forces, accelerations, and Newton's Laws that Derek is trying to explain here. If you know that the gravitational acceleration is different, it is still incorrect to conclude that the forces are different. Derek asked about the forces to point out precisely this mistake.

He specifically asks, "How does the force that the moon exerts on the Earth compare to the force that the Earth exerts on the moon?"

This is as straight forward of a question as there is.  This is clearly a question regarding gravitational FORCE - and NOT field strenght.  The answer to the question is, "it is exactly the same as the force the Earth exerts on the moon, and in the opposite direction - and the reason the moon is accelerated more is due to the moon's lesser inertia"  Got it now?

When you say, "the force on each is the same, but the gravities are not the same", you are talking about the field strength.  This video, and our entire conversation in reference to it....have NOTHING to do with field strength.  Of course the strength of the gravitational field of the moon is weaker than that of the Earth.  Nobody is denying that.  The people in this video who answered his question incorrectly are NOT talking about field strength.  They actually think that the force is weaker.

F=GMm/r²

M is the mass of the Earth
m is the mass of the moon

This is the formula to calculate the gravitational force BETWEEN two objects.  As you can easily see, there is no independent equation to determine the force on EACH because gravity - BY ITS VERY NATURE IS A MUTUAL FORCE.  The force exerted on 'M' is EXACTLY THE SAME as the force exerted on 'm', and that force is proportional to the product of the two masses in question.  If you don't get that concept by now, you're never going to.

Your first problem is the fact that you do not use Newton's gravitational equation to show this.  The notion that light is affected by gravitational fields is a relativistic concept, and therefore Einstein's field equations are the proper equations to use.  This isn't Newtonian mechanics; it is general relativity.  The reason light doesn't have a force component is not because it has zero mass; it is because in the realm where light is attracted to gravitational fields, gravity is not a force.

Inertia is a property of all MASS.  For something to have 'infinite' inertia, it would require 'infinite' mass.  A black hole does not have infinite mass.  Nowehere near it.  It may or may not even have infinite density; THAT concept is a mathematical singularity; not a physical one, though it is usually tentatively projected into the physical world.  Even so, ANY amount of mass will have infinite density if its volume is zero, and its inertia will be consistent with its mass; not density.
The force of gravity you exert on the moon is the same as the force of gravity the moon exerts on you.  They are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction.

That is not what I am talking about.  You are saying that you can accelerate indefinitely, and you can't.  The fundamental point here is the fact that nothing can go the speed of light relative to anything else.  You cannot accelerate for an infinite amount of time because that would require an infinite amount of energy, and even if you could somehow harnass an infinite amount of energy, you would have a finite volume in which to store that energy.  That is not possible. How do you not get this?

That IS how it works, all day long.  That is not a loophole.  If, after accelerating at 9.8m/s^2 for a billion years, you were to look back at the object you passed 10 years ago, you would observe it moving away from you at near c.  If you were to then observe your original starting point, it would be even much closer to c.
That's not at all how it works.  You are just trying to find a loophole where none exists.  Are you claiming that faster than light travel is possible?

You can accelerate with respect to your own original frame of reference.  And each second thereafter establish a new frame of reference and then accelerate relative to it, rinse and repeat forever.  Any object that "glides" past you through inertia in the same direction you will eventually overtake and leave behind at speed approaching c.  No restrictions on your own acceleration whatsoever.

no.  If you are accelerating at 9.8m/s², this has to be relative to SOMETHING, so you cannot accelerate at any rate without respect to some other frame, so it is impossible to define acceleration 'in your own frame'.  ALL motion is relative.  You are just not applying relativistic effects.  I was only applying velocity addition.  There are also mass and energy effects, Lorenz contraction, time dilation, etc.  The point being - you cannot go the speed of light, which was the original point.

Yes, as it applies to the original observer.  My point was, relativity in no way constrains your own motion, or your ability to endlessly accelerate.  In your own frame of reference, you can accelerate at 9.8 m/s^2 forever, and it never becomes harder or easier for you to do so.

You must apply relativistic effects at these velocities, and apply the velocity addition equation :

v3 = (v1+v2)/(1+(v1v2/c²))

v1 = 299,792,457 m/s
v2 = 25 m/s 

Suppose you are traveling at 299,792,457 m/s relative to the Earth, and someone passed you traveling 25 m/s, using the above equation, the velocity of the person who passed you RELATIVE TO EARTH (v3) is still only 299,792,457 m/s.  Nothing can travel faster than c relative to anything else.
Suppose you are going c - 1 mph.  Can someone pass you going 25 mph in the same direction?  Yes.

The moon pulls on the Earth with EXACTLY the same force as the Earth pulls on the moon.  The Earth doesn't 'move' because of its greater amount of inertia.  Inertia doesn't 'move'.  It is just a property of matter.  In fact, the Earth DOES move.  Just not all that much.  It follows a small circular path around the barycenter of the Earth-moon system.  That barycenter is somewhere around 1,700 km below the surface of the Earth, so the Earth doesn't 'wobble' all that much.

Gravity from the Earth causes the moon to continuously redirect its path into an elliptical orbit.  The moon pulls on the Earth with exactly the same force, but the Earth is much more massive and that equal force does not have as great of an effect on the Earth.  The Earth does 'wobble' due to the force from the moon, but not all that much.

F=GMm/r² - Equation to calculate gravitational force.

The 'F' in these two equations are one and the same, so you can then set this equation up :
ma = GMm/r².
m is the mass of you or the moon or whatever.
M is the mass of the Earth
r is the distance to the center of Earth

You see the 'm' cancels on each side, so you are left with :
a=GM/r²
M and r are all that matter (mass of Earth, and distance)
G is a constant

Altitude (distance to the center of Earth, so altitude PLUS the radius of Earth).  The reason changes in latitude are relevant is because Earth is not a perfect sphere.  Obviously there are mountains and valleys.  The rotation causes the Earth to bulge at the equator, so changes in latitude (along the surface) ALSO mean changes in distance to the center, which is what really matters.  The mass of the planet itself is also crucial.  So, basically its the distance, and mass of planet (not you).

The International Space Station orbits around the Earth. Obviously the ISS, which is WAY more massive than an astronaut, doesn't orbit any faster than the astronauts inside.  If it did, astronauts would constantly have to be 'holding on' in order to keep up with the ISS.  This isn't the case because their orbital speed doesn't depend on mass.

Just like how gravity accelerates all objects at the same rate (~9.8m/s² at the surface) regardless of their mass, the same applies for the moon in orbit.  Any object at the same distance from Earth as the moon will orbit at the same rate regardless of the mass.  As long as the center of the mass of the moon remains the same, it doesn't matter how massive it is.  It's orbit will remain the same.

Tletna -- I'm not over simplifying.  You're over-complicating.  The original question was something like, "how can a horse ever get a cart moving if the force exerted on the cart by the horse has is always countered by an equal and opposite force on the force by the cart?".  My answer is perfectly sufficient.  The answer is, the forces don't cancel because they are not acting on the same object.  The net force is a result of the horse pushing on the ground, and the ground pushing back.

The rope is a useful tool though, both for visualizing the problem and simplifying it.  This is one reason we use chains and ropes in real life, it directs the forces.  Also, one cannot just ignore the massive wagon's mass.  If one loads down the wagon or it is tall and there's a strong wind or if objects fall out of the wagon, this will all affect how well the horse can pull it.  Also the wheels are not frictionless in real life so one cannot just say, oh the wagon only has this normal force.

You're over-simplifying here:  What if I'm a child roller-skating by a wagon, which I then hook on the fly as I pass it.  If the child is going fast enough and weighs enough and the wagon is on wheels...well then the child is going to get away with the wagon and it had nothing to do with friction at all.  In fact, it is a lack of friction which allows the situation to occur.
You're right saying one doesn't need the rope though.  The arms of the child act much like braces and a rope.

This is because the wagon has wheels or the child has lifted the wagon or the wagon has handles etc.  Unless you're speaking of electromagnetic or atomic forces, there is no such thing as a pull.  Everything macroscopic is a momentum interaction that results in a mutual push.  When the horse "pulls" the rope, it is actually pushing the harness which pushes the tie, which pushes the rest of the rope, which pushes the other tie, which pushes the parts of the wagon it's tied to, then the wagon.

While the carraige is on wheels.  Just for simplicity's sake, let's assume the mass of the horse, and the mass of the carraige are the same. Neither the horse nor the carriage are immovable objects.  When you push a pencil across the table, that pencil is exerting a force on your hand equal and opposite to the force you exerted on the pencil.  The pencil, however, is not nearly as massive as you, so it has less inertia.  F=ma.  The more mass an object has, the less it accelerates when the forces are equal.  There is a little more going on with the horse-carraige system, but the laws still apply.  The horse gets traction for example.

When you hold an apple in your hand, you are not exerting any force on it (other than providing a normal force, but this even gets complicated when you bring in relativity so Im not getting into it).  When you raise an apple, it is only accelerating for as long as it takes to get moving.  It is not accelerating the whole time you are raising it, but just the hundredths of seconds it took to get moving.  This is why the force will be pretty small, and only last a very short time.

Yes, the scale would register a higher weight.  Technically you did not gain any weight, as your weight is simply the force of gravity on you.  When you exert a force on an apple upward, there is an equal and opposite force exerted on your hand, and by extension the scale.  This is in addition to your weight.  The scale would read your weight PLUS the force exerted on the apple, but only for a split second, or the amount of time the apple was accelerating (maybe a few hundredths of a second)

This is actually really good to demonstrate with magnets. Most people will say that a magnet will exert a force on a piece of iron, but the iron will not exert any force on the magnet. However, you can see if the iron is held securely in one position and the magnet is placed nearby, the iron will exert a force on the magnet, closing the distance. Also, if neither the magnet or the iron are secured, they will move towards each other at the same acceleration (assuming no friction or equal weight).
